- Examples of probability samples include random and stratified sampling; examples of non-probability samples include convenience and judgment sampling.

name: Discuss sampling techniques and issues associated with Internet sampling (IM:440) (SP)
definition:
This involves explaining different methods used to select participants for online research and the challenges they can present.  
- Sampling techniques include random sampling, convenience sampling, and stratified sampling.  
- Issues with Internet sampling may include bias, lack of representation, and privacy concerns.

name: Describe statistical concepts associated with sampling (IM:441) (SP)
definition:
Statistical concepts associated with sampling involve understanding how to select and analyze groups from a larger population to make valid inferences.  
- Sampling methods (e.g., random, stratified)  
- Sampling errors and biases  
- The importance of sample size and representativeness

name: intention scales, etc.) (IM:286) (SP)
definition:
**Intention scales, etc. (IM:286) (SP)**  
Tools like intention scales are used to measure participants' motivations or attitudes.  
- Intention scales  
- Surveys or questionnaires  
- Other measurement tools to assess feelings or plans

name: Apply approaches to increase participant cooperation with data collection (IM:450) (SP)
definition:
Use strategies to encourage people to participate and share information during data collection.  
- Explain the importance of the data  
- Offer incentives or rewards  
- Make the process simple and convenient

name: Administer questionnaires (IM:297) (SP)
definition:
This involves giving out surveys or forms to gather information from people.  
- Distributing questionnaires to target groups  
- Explaining how to complete the questionnaires  
- Collecting the completed questionnaires for analysis

name: Conduct telephone interviews (IM:328) (SP)
definition:
The process of contacting and communicating with individuals by phone to gather information or opinions.  
- Prepare interview questions  
- Call and speak with the interviewee  
- Record their responses accurately

name: video recording) (IM:349) (SP)
definition:
**Video Recording (IM:349) (SP):**  
The process of capturing video footage using recording equipment for later review, analysis, or presentation.  
- Includes recording events, presentations, or demonstrations  
- Can be used for advertising, training, or documenting activities  
- Involves operating recording devices and understanding basic video setup

name: Test alternatives (e.g., web pages, ads, appeals, etc.) (IM:463) (SP)
definition:
Choosing and trying out different options or versions of marketing materials to see which ones work best. Examples include:
- Web pages
- Advertisements
- Messaging appeals

name: Conduct in-depth interviews (IM:322) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves carrying out detailed interviews to gather information.  
- Prepare for the interview by researching the topic or person.  
- Ask open-ended questions to encourage detailed responses.  
- Listen actively and take notes to understand the interviewee's perspectives.

name: Edit/clean research data (IM:348) (SP)
definition:
The process of reviewing and correcting research data to ensure accuracy and consistency.  
- Checking for errors or inconsistencies  
- Removing duplicate or irrelevant data  
- Organizing data in a clear and usable format

name: Code research data (IM:362) (SP)
definition:
This indicator involves understanding how to organize and record research data using appropriate coding methods.  
- Assigning codes to data categories or variables  
- Using coding systems to simplify data analysis  
- Ensuring accurate and consistent data coding

name: Apply methods to treat missing data (IM:451) (SP)
definition:
Learn how to handle data that has missing information by using different techniques.  
- Use methods such as data imputation, deletion, or substitution  
- Decide when to apply each method based on the data situation  
- Improve data quality and analysis accuracy by properly treating missing data

name: Conduct error detection/edit routines (IM:318) (SP)
definition:
The ability to review and correct work to find and fix mistakes.  
- Check for errors in data or documents  
- Correct any identified mistakes  
- Ensure accuracy and completeness before finalizing

name: Transcribe conversations/interviews (IM:452) (SP)
definition:
The ability to accurately listen to and write down spoken conversations or interviews.  
- Listening carefully to spoken words  
- Writing down spoken words accurately  
- Organizing the transcription clearly

name: Tabulate data (IM:402) (SP)
definition:
Organize and display collected data in a table to make it easier to understand and analyze.  

- Arrange data into rows and columns
- Include labels for each column
- Summarize data to identify patterns or trends

name: Create data matrix (IM:331) (SP)
definition:
Create a data matrix (IM:331) (SP)

A data matrix is a structured table that organizes data into rows and columns to help analyze information easily. 

- Example elements:
  - Variables or categories written as column headers
  - Data points entered into the corresponding cells
  - Clear labels for each row and column

name: Select and use appropriate data support systems (IM:397) (SP)
definition:
Choosing and applying the correct technology tools or software to collect, store, and analyze data needed for business decisions and activities. Examples include:
- Spreadsheets
- Databases
- Data analysis software

name: selecting mechanical analysis approaches) (IM:304) (SP)
definition:
Selecting mechanical analysis approaches involves choosing the best methods to examine and solve technical problems related to machinery or mechanical systems. This helps in diagnosing issues, designing solutions, and improving equipment performance.  
Examples include:
- Finite element analysis
- Stress and strain analysis
- Thermal analysis

name: Set confidence levels (IM:400) (SP)
definition:
Determine and state the appropriate confidence level to use when making decisions or analyzing data.  
   - Select a confidence level (e.g., 90%, 95%)  
   - Understand the purpose of confidence levels in statistics  
   - Use the confidence level to interpret data accuracy and reliability

name: Test for relationships (IM:404) (SP)
definition:
refers to analyzing and identifying connections between two or more variables or concepts.  
Examples include:
- Finding correlations between different data points
- Determining if changes in one variable affect another
- Recognizing patterns that show how things are related

name: Test for associations (IM:403) (SP)
definition:
A process used to find relationships or connections between different data or ideas.  
- Identify how two or more items are related  
- Check for patterns or links  
- Use different methods like surveys or experiments to find associations

name: Test for significant differences (IM:405) (SP)
definition:
A method used to determine whether the differences between two or more groups are meaningful and not due to chance.  

- Examples include t-tests and ANOVA.

name: Use statistical inferences to make estimates or to test hypotheses (IM:412) (SP)
definition:
Use statistical inferences to make conclusions or test ideas about data.  
- Making estimates from sample data  
- Testing hypotheses to see if ideas are supported by data  
- Drawing conclusions about a larger group based on a smaller sample

name: Identify types of modeling techniques (IM:369) (SP)
definition:
Recognize different methods used to create visual or mathematical representations of data or processes.  
   - Graph models  
   - Flowcharts  
   - Simulation models

name: Apply mathematical modeling techniques (IM:308) (SP)
definition:
Use mathematical methods to create models that represent real-world business situations, helping analyze options and make decisions.  
- Develop equations or graphs to simulate business scenarios  
- Use data to predict outcomes  
- Solve problems by adjusting models to find the best solution

name: Interpret descriptive statistics for marketing decision making (IM:416) (SP)
definition:
Understanding and explaining simple statistical data to help make marketing decisions.  
- Analyzing measures like averages, medians, and modes  
- Summarizing data with charts and graphs  
- Using data to identify trends and patterns

name: Interpret correlations (IM:370) (SP)
definition:
Understanding how two variables are related is important in analyzing data. When interpreting correlations, you examine how changes in one variable correspond to changes in another. 

- Recognize positive, negative, and no correlation
- Determine the strength of the relationship (strong or weak)
- Apply the interpretation to business or marketing contexts

name: Display data in charts/graphs or in tables (IM:347) (SP)
definition:
The ability to organize and present data clearly using visual tools.  
- Creating charts or graphs  
- Organizing data into tables  
- Using visual displays to show information effectively

name: Write executive summary of research report (IM:414) (SP)
definition:
Create a brief overview of a research report that highlights the main points and findings.  
- Summarize key purpose and objectives  
- Include important results and conclusions  
- Keep it clear and concise for quick understanding

name: Prepare and use presentation software to support reports (IM:386) (SP)
definition:
Learn to create and use presentation software to enhance reports and communicate information effectively.  
- Use presentation programs like PowerPoint or Google Slides  
- Add text, images, and charts to slides  
- Present information clearly and professionally

name: Present findings orally (IM:391) (SP)
definition:
Deliver information or research results clearly and confidently through spoken communication.  
- Organize your ideas logically  
- Use appropriate voice tone and clarity  
- Support your presentation with relevant details or data

name: Prepare written reports for decision-making (IM:390) (SP)
definition:
Prepare written reports for decision-making involves creating clear documents that analyze information to help people make business choices.  
- Summarize relevant data or facts  
- Present findings in an organized way  
- Include recommendations or conclusions to support decisions

name: Post marketing research results electronically (IM:383) (SP)
definition:
This means sharing the findings of marketing research through electronic methods. 

- Examples include emails, online reports, or databases.

name: Pre-test promotional campaign (e.g., advertising, direct marketing, etc.) (IM:392) (SP)
definition:
This refers to marketing activities done before a product or service is launched to generate interest and awareness.  
- Advertising  
- Direct marketing  
- Other promotional strategies used before the launch

name: Measure media audience (IM:374) (SP)
definition:
The ability to analyze and determine the size and demographics of a media audience.  
- Examples include TV ratings, radio listenership, or website traffic data.

name: Measure response rates (IM:375) (SP)
definition:
The ability to calculate and analyze the percentage of people who respond to a survey, questionnaire, or communication.  
- Determine the number of responses received  
- Determine the total number of people invited to respond  
- Calculate the response rate by dividing responses by total invitations and multiplying by 100

name: Conduct advertising tracking studies (IM:313) (SP)
definition:
This involves measuring and analyzing how well advertising campaigns are performing over time. It helps businesses understand the effectiveness of their advertising efforts.

- Collect data on advertising reach, frequency, and audience response
- Analyze changes in brand awareness and sales
- Use the results to improve future advertising strategies

name: Identify the effects of global trade on retailing (EC:094) (SP)
definition:
Understand how international trade influences retail businesses.  
- Changes in product availability and variety  
- Impact on prices and costs  
- Effects on local and international retailers

name: Explain current retail trends driven by global trade (EC:102) (SP)
definition:
This indicator involves describing how global trade influences recent changes in retail, such as new shopping methods, product availability, and store formats.

- Increased online shopping and e-commerce
- Greater variety of products available internationally
- Rise of international brands and stores

name: Distinguish between retailing and marketing (MK:003) (CS)
definition:
Understanding the difference between retailing and marketing is important for business.  
- **Retailing** involves selling products directly to consumers through stores or online platforms.  
- **Marketing** includes all activities a business does to promote and sell products, such as advertising, market research, and pricing strategies.

name: Explain the importance of merchandising to retailers (MK:020) (CS)
definition:
Merchandising is crucial for retailers because it helps attract customers and increase sales. It involves:

- Choosing the right products to sell
- Arranging products to catch customers' attention
- Pricing and promoting items effectively

name: Analyze the impact of technology on retailing (NF:041) (SP)
definition:
Analyze how technology affects retailing, including:
- how it improves customer shopping experiences
- how it changes sales and marketing strategies
- how it influences store operations and management

name: Utilize merchandising software (NF:107) (SP)
definition:
Use specialized computer programs to manage and support merchandising activities.  
   - Track inventory and sales  
   - Adjust product displays  
   - Analyze sales data

name: Obtain information from retail databases to aid in product planning and control (NF:104) (SP)
definition:
Gather and use data from retail databases to help make decisions about which products to sell, how much to keep in stock, and when to restock.  
- Access sales and inventory data  
- Analyze customer purchase patterns  
- Use information to plan and manage products effectively

name: Maintain purchase orders (NF:102) (SP)
definition:
The process of keeping accurate and organized records of purchase orders to ensure proper tracking and management of business purchases.

- Prepare purchase orders
- Update order status
- Keep records of received goods and payments

name: Maintain order logs (NF:108) (SP)
definition:
Record and organize customer orders accurately to keep track of sales and ensure proper processing.  
- Record order details (items, quantities, prices)  
- Update logs regularly to reflect new and completed orders  
- Maintain organized and accessible order records

name: Explain policies/procedures for handling shoplifters (OP:122) (CS)
definition:
Explain policies and procedures for handling shoplifters (OP:122) (CS).  
This involves understanding the rules and steps a store follows when dealing with suspected shoplifters.  
- Identifying shoplifting behaviors  
- Notifying store security or management  
- Following legal and store guidelines for detaining and reporting the incident

name: Devise/Enact merchandise security measures to minimize inventory shrinkage (OP:172) (SP)
definition:
Creating and implementing security procedures to protect merchandise and reduce losses from theft, damage, or errors.  
- Installing security tags and alarms  
- Monitoring and controlling access to inventory  
- Conducting regular inventory checks

name: Follow up orders (OP:040) (CS)
definition:
The process of checking on and ensuring that customer orders are completed accurately and on time.  
- Confirm order details with customers  
- Track order status and progress  
- Resolve any issues or delays with orders

name: Prepare cash drawers/banks (OP:194) (CS)
definition:
The process of organizing and setting up cash on hand for transactions.  
- Counting cash and checks  
- Balancing cash register with sales records  
- Organizing cash in the drawer or bank deposit

name: Open/Close register/terminal (OP:195) (CS)
definition:
**Open/Close Register/Terminal (OP:195) (CS)**  
Knowing how to properly open and close a cash register or terminal is essential for accurate sales and cash handling.  
- Opens the register at the start of a shift  
- Closes the register at the end of a shift or day  
- Counts and documents cash and sales totals during opening and closing

name: Explain the nature and scope of distribution (OP:522) (CS)
definition:
This performance indicator involves understanding what distribution is and how it works in business. It explains the process of getting products from manufacturers to customers. 

Key points include:
- The role of distribution in the supply chain
- Types of distribution channels (like retail stores, online, wholesale)
- The importance of distribution in meeting customer needs and ensuring product availability

name: Explain the relationship between customer service and distribution (OP:523) (CS)
definition:
Customer service and distribution are connected because good distribution ensures products are delivered accurately and on time, which keeps customers satisfied and loyal.  

- Quick and reliable product delivery  
- Proper communication with customers during delivery  
- Meeting customer needs through efficient distribution

name: Describe the use of technology in distribution (OP:524) (SP)
definition:
Explain how technology helps in distributing products.  
- Tracks inventory and shipments  
- Manages supply chain information  
- Improves delivery efficiency

name: Explain legal considerations in distribution (OP:525) (SP)
definition:
Understanding legal considerations in distribution involves knowing the rules and laws that businesses must follow when selling and delivering products. 

- Follow laws related to product labeling and packaging
- Comply with regulations on shipping and delivery procedures
- Ensure contracts and sales agreements meet legal standards

name: Describe ethical considerations in distribution (OP:526) (SP)
definition:
Understanding ethical considerations in distribution involves recognizing the importance of honesty and fairness when delivering products. Key elements include:
- Ensuring truthful communication with customers about products and services
- Maintaining product safety and quality standards
- Respecting confidentiality and protecting customer information

name: Explain distribution issues and trends (OP:377) (SP)
definition:
Understand common problems and changes in product distribution.  
- Distribution issues such as delays, damaged goods, or incorrect shipments  
- Trends like the adoption of new technology or changes in delivery methods  
- Factors that influence distribution, including cost, speed, and customer needs

name: Discuss the use of electronic data interchange (EDI) (OP:378) (SP)
definition:
**Discuss the use of electronic data interchange (EDI)**

Electronic Data Interchange (EDI) is the computer-to-computer exchange of business documents between companies.  
It is used to improve business efficiency and accuracy.  
Examples include:  
- Sending purchase orders electronically  
- Sending invoices automatically  
- Sharing shipping notices between businesses

name: Use an information system for order fulfillment (OP:380) (CS)
definition:
Use an information system to process and complete customer orders efficiently.  
- Enter order details  
- Track order status  
- Update inventory and shipment information

name: Fulfill orders (OP:381) (CS)
definition:
The process of completing a customer's purchase by preparing and delivering the ordered products or services.  
- Picking the items from inventory  
- Packing the products securely  
- Shipping or delivering the order to the customer

name: Explain the receiving process (OP:384) (CS)
definition:
The receiving process involves checking and accepting goods that a business receives from suppliers. It includes confirming the order details, inspecting items for quality and accuracy, and recording the delivery. 

- Verify that the delivered items match the order
- Inspect items for damage or defects
- Record receipt of goods in inventory or receiving records

name: Explain stock-handling techniques used in receiving deliveries (OP:385) (CS)
definition:
**Stock-handling techniques used in receiving deliveries** refer to the methods employees use to properly manage and store products when new shipments arrive.  
Key techniques include:
- Checking the delivery against the order list
- Recording and labeling items correctly
- Moving and storing products carefully to prevent damage

name: Process incoming merchandise (OP:386) (CS)
definition:
The process of handling and checking products received from suppliers to ensure they are correct and ready for sale.  
- Checking delivery invoices  
- Inspecting items for damage or defects  
- Organizing and storing merchandise properly

name: Resolve problems with incoming shipments (OP:387) (CS)
definition:
This means identifying and fixing issues that occur when receiving shipments.  
- Checking for damaged or missing items  
- Communicating with suppliers or shipping companies  
- Ensuring shipments are accurate and complete

name: Attach source and anti-theft tags (OP:389) (CS)
definition:
This involves placing security tags on products to prevent theft, with the tags either indicating the product’s source or serving as anti-theft devices.

- Attach source tags to identify the product or supplier
- Attach anti-theft tags to prevent shoplifting
- Use appropriate tools and techniques to secure the tags properly

name: Price mark merchandise (OP:390) (CS)
definition:
The process of labeling products with their selling price to inform customers and facilitate sales.  
- Applying price tags or labels to items  
- Updating prices on merchandise when needed  
- Ensuring prices are clear and accurate for customers

name: Make and record price changes (OP:391) (SP)
definition:
The ability to adjust the prices of products or services and keep accurate records of those changes.  
- Changing prices based on market or company decisions  
- Documenting the date and reason for each price change  
- Updating price information in sales records or systems

name: Identify hang-tag needs (OP:392) (SP)
definition:
Determine what information and labels are needed on hang-tags for products.  
- Product details (e.g., name, price)  
- Branding or logo  
- Safety or warning messages

name: Assign codes to each product item (OP:393) (SP)
definition:
The process of giving a unique identification number or code to each product to help organize and track inventory, sales, and records.  
- Example codes may include UPCs, SKU numbers, or barcodes.

name: Route stock to sales floor (OP:394) (CS)
definition:
This performance indicator involves moving products from storage or backroom to the sales floor so they are available for customers to purchase.  

- Properly organizing and replenishing merchandise  
- Ensuring popular items are in stock on the sales floor  
- Following store procedures for stocking items

name: Rotate stock (OP:395) (CS)
definition:
The process of arranging products so that older items are sold before newer ones to reduce spoilage and maintain freshness.  
- Includes organizing items on shelves  
- Ensuring products are used or sold in the correct order  
- Helps prevent items from becoming outdated or expired

name: Process returned/damaged product (OP:396) (CS)
definition:
Refers to handling and managing products that are returned by customers or received damaged.  

- Inspecting returned or damaged items  
- Determining if the product can be repaired, resold, or needs disposal  
- Documenting the condition and processing the return or damage properly

name: Transfer stock to/from branches (OP:397) (SP)
definition:
Moving inventory items between different store locations or branches to ensure proper stock levels and inventory management.  
   - transferring stock from one branch to another  
   - recording the transfer details  
   - updating inventory records after the transfer

name: Enter product descriptions into a PoS system (OP:398) (SP)
definition:
Enter product descriptions into a Point of Sale (PoS) system.  
This involves adding detailed information about products to the system to help with sales and inventory tracking.  
- Write clear product names  
- Include product details like size or color  
- Input prices and other relevant information

name: Explain storing considerations (OP:400) (CS)
definition:
Understanding how to store products properly to maintain quality and safety.  
- Temperature control  
- Packaging and labeling  
- Storage location and organization

name: Explain the nature of warehousing (OP:401) (CS)
definition:
Warehousing involves storing goods safely until they are needed for sale or distribution.  

- It includes storing products in warehouses or storage facilities.  
- Ensures products are kept in good condition and protected from damage.  
- Helps businesses manage inventory and meet customer demand efficiently.

name: Store inventory (OP:402) (CS)
definition:
**Store Inventory (OP:402) (CS)**

The process of managing and controlling the items a store has on hand to meet customer demand and prevent shortages or excess.

- Tracking quantities of products
- Reordering stock when needed
- Organizing inventory to make products easy to find

name: Explain shipping processes (OP:405) (CS)
definition:
Understanding how products are moved from the seller to the buyer.  
- Preparing items for shipment  
- Choosing shipping options and carriers  
- Tracking and delivering packages

name: Identify factors considered when selecting best shipping method (OP:406) (SP)
definition:
**Identify factors considered when selecting the best shipping method (OP:406) (SP)**

Understanding the important elements that influence choosing the most suitable shipping method. These factors often include:
- Cost of shipping
- Delivery speed
- Distance and destination
- Size and weight of the shipment
- Nature of the goods (e.g., fragile, perishable)

name: Maintain inventory levels (OP:407) (CS)
definition:
The process of keeping the right amount of products in stock to meet customer demand and avoid excess or shortages. This includes:
- Monitoring stock levels regularly
- Reordering products when needed
- Managing stock to prevent overstocking or stockouts

name: Report out-of-stocks (OP:408) (CS)
definition:
involves identifying and documenting when products are not available on the shelves.  
- Examples include missing popular items or stock running low.  
- It helps ensure inventory is maintained and customer needs are met.

name: Complete inventory counts (OP:409) (CS)
definition:
The process of checking and recording the quantities of products on hand to ensure accurate inventory records.  
- Includes counting all items in stock  
- Ensures records match physical stock  
- Helps identify shortages or excess inventory

name: Monitor merchandise classification system (OP:410) (SP)
definition:
Regularly review and ensure the accuracy of the system used to categorize products. This helps keep inventory organized and easy to manage.  
- Check that products are correctly labeled and classified  
- Update categories as needed for new or changed products  
- Correct any errors found during monitoring

name: Allocate merchandise to stores/regions (OP:411) (SP)
definition:
The process of distributing products to different store locations or regions based on demand and sales forecasts.  
- Identifying the needs of each store or region  
- Selecting appropriate products to send  
- Determining the quantity of merchandise to allocate

name: Track stock by location for department/class/vendor level (OP:412) (SP)
definition:
Track stock by location for department, class, or vendor level (OP:412) (SP)

This performance indicator involves monitoring inventory levels across different locations.  
- Record stock quantities by specific department, class, or vendor.  
- Keep track of where products are stored.  
- Ensure accurate inventory counts across all locations.

name: Describe inventory control systems (OP:413) (CS)
definition:
Inventory control systems are methods used to track and manage inventory levels. They help ensure that a business has the right amount of stock without overstocking or running out.  
- Examples include manual record keeping, barcode systems, and automated inventory software.

name: Explain types of unit inventory-control systems (OP:414) (SP)
definition:
**Types of unit inventory-control systems** refer to methods used to keep track of inventory at the individual item level.  
These systems include:  
- **Perpetual Inventory System:** Continuously tracks inventory updates after each sale or receipt.  
- **Periodic Inventory System:** Updates inventory counts at specific intervals, such as weekly or monthly.  
- **Manual Inventory System:** Uses physical counting and record-keeping without automated tools.

name: Determine inventory shrinkage (OP:415) (SP)
definition:
The process of calculating the loss of inventory due to theft, errors, or damage.  
- Identifying the difference between inventory records and physical stock  
- Calculating the amount of lost inventory  
- Understanding factors that cause inventory shrinkage

name: Maintain inventory-control systems (OP:416) (SP)
definition:
Develop and implement methods to keep track of inventory levels, ensure accurate stock counts, and manage stock movements efficiently.  
- Use inventory tracking tools or software  
- Perform regular inventory counts  
- Organize and record inventory data accurately

name: Implement category management process (OP:417) (SP)
definition:
Implement the category management process (OP:417) (SP): This involves developing and applying a strategic approach to organize and manage product categories to maximize sales and profitability.  
- Analyze sales data and trends  
- Develop category plans and strategies  
- Work with suppliers and teams to optimize product assortment

name: Ensure timely delivery of advertised merchandise (OP:420) (SP)
definition:
Making sure that products promised in advertisements are delivered to customers on time.  
- Track delivery schedules  
- Communicate delivery updates to customers  
- Meet delivery deadlines as promised

name: Explain the evolution of retailing (PD:148) (CS)
definition:
Describe how retailing has changed over time, including key developments and trends that have shaped modern shopping.  
- The shift from traditional storefronts to online shopping  
- Use of technology and automation in stores  
- Changes in consumer preferences and shopping behaviors

name: Describe the role of merchandisers in retailing (PD:128) (CS)
definition:
**Role of Merchandisers in Retailing (PD:128) (CS)**

Merchandisers plan and organize the display and promotion of products to attract customers and increase sales. Their role includes:
- Selecting and ordering products
- Setting up displays and signs
- Monitoring inventory and sales data

name: Identify career opportunities in retailing (PD:038) (CS)
definition:
Recognize various jobs and roles available in the retail industry.  
   - Store management  
   - Sales associate  
   - Merchandising and purchasing

name: Explain career opportunities in merchandising (PD:134) (CS)
definition:
Understand the different job opportunities available in merchandising. This includes:
- Buying products for stores
- Selling and promoting products
- Managing retail operations

name: Determine the impact of product standards' issues associated with global business (PM:278) (SP)
definition:
Understand how problems with product standards affect international trade and business operations.  
- Recognize common product standard issues in global markets  
- Assess how these issues influence product acceptance and compliance  
- Identify potential challenges and solutions related to product standards in international business

name: Obtain samples (PM:253) (SP)
definition:
involves collecting specific products or materials to analyze or use for a business purpose.  
- Examples include product samples, customer feedback, or inventory items.  
- It ensures the right items are gathered for testing, display, or decision-making purposes.

name: Determine quality of merchandise to offer (PM:223) (SP)
definition:
Determine the quality of merchandise to offer involves assessing whether products meet certain standards.  
- It includes checking product condition, durability, and safety.  
- Ensuring merchandise is appealing and meets customer needs.  
- Making decisions on whether to stock, keep, or remove products based on their quality.

name: Plan merchandise assortment (e.g., styling, sizes, quantities, colors) (PM:254) (SP)
definition:
Deciding which products to stock by choosing the styles, sizes, quantities, and colors needed to meet customer demand and sales goals.  
- Style options (e.g., clothing styles)  
- Sizes available (e.g., small, medium, large)  
- Quantities of each product (how much to order)  
- Colors of products (e.g., red, blue, green)

name: Explain the nature of merchandise plans (budgets) (PM:061) (SP)
definition:
Merchandise plans (budgets) are detailed plans that outline the estimated sales, costs, and profits for a merchandise business over a certain period. They help businesses manage inventory, control expenses, and achieve financial goals.

- Include sales projections
- Cover cost estimates
- Help with inventory planning

name: Calculate open-to-buy (PM:058) (SP)
definition:
Open-to-buy is the amount of money a retailer has available to spend on new inventory. To calculate it:
- Start with the planned sales for the upcoming period
- Add planned markdowns and purchases
- Subtract expected ending inventory and sales from the current period

name: Create/maintain daily sales plan (PM:219) (SP)
definition:
Create or keep an up-to-date daily sales plan to organize and set goals for daily sales activities.  
- Identify sales targets for the day  
- Plan specific sales activities or outreach  
- Track progress and adjust as needed

name: Identify emerging trends (PM:257) (SP)
definition:
Recognize new or developing patterns in the marketplace, industry, or consumer behavior.  
- Examples include new technologies, changing customer preferences, or emerging competitors.

name: Plan stock (PM:062) (SP)
definition:
The process of organizing and managing inventory to ensure products are available when needed.  
- determines the amount of stock to keep  
- sets reorder points and quantities  
- considers sales trends and storage capacity

name: (PM:063) (SP)
definition:
This indicator focuses on understanding and applying basic pricing strategies in marketing. 

It includes:
- Setting prices based on costs and market conditions
- Using competitive pricing techniques
- Understanding the impact of pricing on sales and profits

name: Plan purchases (PM:064) (SP)
definition:
The process of determining what to buy, when to buy, and how much to buy to meet business needs efficiently.  

Includes:  
- Setting a budget  
- Selecting suppliers  
- Scheduling purchase timelines

name: Compare and contrast buying from domestic sources with that of foreign sources (PM:192) (SP)
definition:
Understanding the differences between purchasing products from local (domestic) companies versus international (foreign) companies.  
- Domestic sources: products made or sold by local companies within your country.  
- Foreign sources: products made or sold by companies in other countries.  
- Factors to consider include cost, quality, shipping time, and import regulations.

name: Determine final cost of purchases from domestic and international sources (PM:193) (SP)
definition:
Determine the final cost of purchases from domestic and international sources involves calculating the total amount spent on goods or services after including all related expenses. 

- Items to consider include:
  - Purchase price of the item
  - Shipping and freight costs
  - Import duties and tariffs (for international sources)

name: Write purchase orders (PM:258) (SP)
definition:
The process of creating a formal document used to request the purchase of goods or services.  
- Includes identifying the needed items  
- Listing supplier information and prices  
- Sending the order to the vendor

name: Analyze the use of central buying (PM:259) (SP)
definition:
Understanding how companies purchase goods and services through a centralized process.  
- Assessing the advantages and disadvantages of central buying  
- Explaining how central buying affects purchasing efficiency and costs  
- Identifying situations when central buying is most effective

name: Determine stock turnover (PM:224) (SP)
definition:
The process of calculating how many times a company's inventory is sold and replaced over a specific period.  
- Understand the formula: Cost of Goods Sold ÷ Average Inventory  
- Use it to assess inventory efficiency and sales performance  
- Apply the results to improve inventory management

name: Determine what to buy/reorder (PM:260) (SP)
definition:
Determine what items to buy or reorder to keep inventory levels appropriate.  
- Analyze sales trends and inventory levels  
- Decide on reorder quantities  
- Choose products to restock based on demand

name: Determine quantities to buy/reorder (PM:261) (SP)
definition:
Determine quantities to buy or reorder involves calculating how much of a product a business needs to purchase again to meet customer demand and maintain inventory levels.  
- Includes analyzing sales data and inventory levels  
- Helps prevent stockouts or overstocking  
- Involves applying reorder point formulas and safety stock considerations

name: Determine when to buy/reorder (PM:262) (SP)
definition:
Recognize the right time to purchase or reorder inventory to ensure enough stock without overstocking.  
- Monitor inventory levels  
- Consider lead time from suppliers  
- Analyze sales trends and demand

name: Establish reorder points (PM:232) (SP)
definition:
**Establish Reorder Points (PM:232) (SP):**  
Setting a specific inventory level at which new stock should be ordered to prevent stock shortages.  
- Determine average usage rate  
- Consider lead time for delivery  
- Set the reorder point accordingly

name: Evaluate vendors' goods and services (PM:239) (SP)
definition:
Evaluate vendors’ goods and services refers to analyzing and comparing what different vendors offer to determine the best choices.  
- Considers quality, price, and delivery times of products or services  
- Checks if vendors meet company standards and needs  
- Looks for value and reliability in vendor offerings

name: Choose vendors (PM:263) (SP)
definition:
The process of selecting suppliers or providers for a business’s needs.  
- Research potential vendors  
- Evaluate vendor options based on cost, quality, and reliability  
- Make a final decision and establish a vendor relationship

name: Negotiate terms with suppliers (PM:264) (SP)
definition:
Negotiate terms with suppliers involves discussing and agreeing on the conditions of a purchase. This includes:

- Price and payment arrangements
- Delivery schedules
- Quality standards and warranties

name: Identify components of a retail image (PM:243) (SP)
definition:
Understanding the key elements that create a store’s overall impression to customers.  
- Store exterior appearance  
- Interior layout and cleanliness  
- Signage and branding

name: Analyze information from suppliers (IM:300) (SP)
definition:
Examine data provided by suppliers to make informed business decisions. This includes evaluating:
- supplier capabilities and reliability
- costs and pricing information
- delivery times and quality standards

name: Scan marketplace to identify factors that could influence merchandising decisions (IM:396) (SP)
definition:
The process of observing and gathering information about the marketplace to understand events or trends that may impact merchandising choices.  
- Economic conditions  
- Competitor actions  
- Customer preferences

name: Analyze competitors' offerings (IM:298) (SP)
definition:
This means examining and understanding the products or services that competitors provide.  
- Identify competitors’ products or services  
- Compare features, quality, and pricing  
- Recognize what makes competitors’ offerings unique or appealing

name: Proof ads (PR:346) (SP)
definition:
The process of reviewing and verifying advertising materials to ensure they are accurate, truthful, and meet company and legal standards.  
   - Checking for correct information  
   - Ensuring proper spelling and grammar  
   - Confirming compliance with regulations

name: Plan special events (PR:360) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves organizing and preparing for special events to ensure they run smoothly.  
- Determine event goals and objectives  
- Coordinate logistics and activities  
- Promote the event to target audiences

name: Prepare store/department for special event (PR:068) (SP)
definition:
Getting the store or department ready for a special event involves planning and organizing to ensure everything is in place. 

- Set up displays and signage
- Stock or replenish products
- Arrange staff schedules and assign duties

name: Explain the use of visual merchandising in retailing (PR:023) (CS)
definition:
**Use of Visual Merchandising in Retailing (PR:023) (CS):**  
Understanding how visual merchandising attracts customers and encourages purchases in retail settings.  
- Creating appealing displays to highlight products  
- Using signs, colors, and lighting effectively  
- Arranging products to guide customer flow and maximize sales

name: Distinguish between visual merchandising and display (PR:302) (CS)
definition:
Understand the difference between visual merchandising and display:
- **Visual merchandising** involves creating attractive store layouts and product arrangements to encourage shopping.
- **Display** refers to showcasing specific products in a way that highlights them and attracts customer attention.

name: Place merchandise for impact (PR:342) (SP)
definition:
Arranging products in a way that attracts customers’ attention and encourages purchases.  
- Use of displays and signage  
- Proper spacing of items  
- Grouping similar products together

name: Determine on-floor assortments (PR:284) (SP)
definition:
Deciding what products or items should be displayed together on the sales floor to attract customers and meet sales goals.  
   - Selecting the right mix of products  
   - Arranging products for visual appeal  
   - Ensuring product placement matches customer needs

name: Use cross-merchandising techniques (PR:358) (SP)
definition:
Using strategies to promote multiple related products together to increase sales.  
- Display complementary products near each other  
- Create themed product displays  
- Suggest related items to customers to encourage additional purchases

name: Read/Implement planograms (PR:349) (SP)
definition:
The ability to understand and follow a planogram, which is a visual layout that shows how products should be displayed.  
- Analyzing the planogram to understand product placement  
- Arranging products according to the planogram  
- Ensuring the display matches the planogram details

name: Explain types of display arrangements (PR:026) (CS)
definition:
This performance indicator involves describing different ways products can be arranged for display to attract customers.  
Types include:
- Grid display: products arranged in straight, evenly spaced rows and columns.
- Free-form display: products arranged creatively or artistically without a set pattern.
- Bin or gondola display: products placed in bins or on low shelves for easy access.

name: Maintain displays (PR:052) (CS)
definition:
Keep product displays tidy, organized, and well-stocked to attract customers and encourage sales.  
   - Arrange products neatly  
   - Replenish items as needed  
   - Ensure signage and displays are clean and appealing

name: Dismantle/Store displays/display fixtures/forms (PR:054) (CS)
definition:
The ability to safely take apart and store store displays, fixtures, and display forms when they are no longer in use or need to be moved.  
- Dismantle shelving units or displays  
- Store fixtures properly for future use  
- Ensure displays are taken apart correctly without damage

name: Create promotional signs (PR:109) (SP)
definition:
Design visual displays to advertise or promote a product, service, or event.  
- Use attention-grabbing images and text  
- Include clear and concise messages  
- Make signs visually appealing and easy to read

name: Select and use display fixtures/forms (PR:031) (SP)
definition:
Choosing and properly using display fixtures or forms to showcase products effectively.  
- Examples include shelves, mannequins, trade show displays, and signage.  
- Ensuring fixtures are appropriate for the product and setting.  
- Arranging fixtures to attract customers and highlight products.

name: Use lighting to highlight products (PR:359) (SP)
definition:
Use lighting to draw attention to products and make them more appealing.  
- Properly position lights to highlight key items  
- Use bright or focused lighting to emphasize products  
- Adjust lighting to improve product visibility and attractiveness

name: Set up point-of-sale displays and handouts (PR:114) (SP)
definition:
involves preparing and arranging marketing materials at the selling location.  
- Includes creating eye-catching displays  
- Placing informational or promotional handouts  
- Arranging materials to attract customer attention

name: Create displays (PR:047) (SP)
definition:
Design and set up visual displays to promote products, services, or ideas.  
- Plan the layout and design  
- Select and arrange products or visuals  
- Ensure displays are attractive and informative

name: Develop promotional calendar (PR:209) (SP)
definition:
Creating a schedule that outlines all promotional activities and marketing efforts planned for a specific period to ensure organized and timely promotion of products or services.  
Includes:
- Identifying key promotional events
- Scheduling marketing campaigns
- Planning advertising and sales activities

name: Plan/Schedule displays/themes with management (PR:077) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves creating and presenting plans or schedules that include displays or themes related to the business. It shows organization and coordination with management. Examples include:
- Developing a display plan for a store event
- Creating a schedule for a promotional theme
- Presenting the display ideas to management for approval

name: Explain the use of brand names in selling (SE:019) (CS)
definition:
**Explanation of the use of brand names in selling (SE:019) (CS):**  
The use of brand names in selling involves referencing specific product brands to attract customers and boost sales.  
- Builds customer trust and recognition  
- Highlights product quality or reputation  
- Differentiates products from competitors

name: Establish relationship with customer/client (SE:110) (CS)
definition:
Building trust and rapport with customers or clients to create a positive connection.  
   - Greeting and welcoming the customer  
   - Listening to their needs and concerns  
   - Showing genuine interest and friendliness

name: Determine customer/client needs (SE:111) (CS)
definition:
refers to identifying what customers or clients want or need from a product or service. This includes:

- Asking questions to understand their preferences
- Listening carefully to their responses
- Analyzing their buying habits and feedback

name: Recommend specific product (SE:114) (CS)
definition:
Suggest a particular product to a customer based on their needs and preferences.  
- Identify the customer’s needs  
- Match features of a product to those needs  
- Clearly explain why the product is a good choice

name: Demonstrate good/service (SE:374) (SP)
definition:
Show how to effectively provide a good or service to customers, focusing on quality, efficiency, and customer satisfaction.  
- Explain the features of a product or service  
- Offer solutions to customer needs  
- Ensure delivery meets quality standards

name: Convert customer/client objections into selling points (SE:874) (SP)
definition:
This involves turning customer concerns or objections into reasons to buy by highlighting benefits or solutions.  

- Address the customer's concerns  
- Explain how the product or service meets their needs  
- Use objections as opportunities to emphasize advantages

name: Close the sale (SE:895) (SP)
definition:
The ability to successfully help a customer make a purchasing decision and complete a transaction.  
- Address customer concerns  
- Confirm the customer's needs are met  
- Ask for the sale or purchase decision

name: Demonstrate suggestion selling (SE:875) (SP)
definition:
The ability to recommend additional products or services to customers to increase sales.  
- Offering complementary items  
- Recommending upgrades or accessories  
- Explaining the benefits of additional purchases

name: Plan follow-up strategies for use in retail selling (SE:489) (SP)
definition:
Develop methods to contact and assist customers after a sale to encourage repeat business and build relationships.  
- Sending thank-you notes or emails  
- Checking in with customers to ensure satisfaction  
- Offering additional products or promotions

name: Arrange delivery of purchases (SE:023) (CS)
definition:
The process of organizing and planning how purchased goods will be delivered to the business or customer.  
- Schedule delivery times  
- Choose delivery methods (e.g., shipping or courier)  
- Ensure delivery details are confirmed and accurate

name: Pack and wrap purchases (SE:887) (CS)
definition:
The process of preparing purchased items for delivery or storage by packaging and wrapping them properly.  

- Protects items during transport or handling  
- Ensures items stay clean and undamaged  
- Uses suitable packaging materials, such as boxes, bubble wrap, or wrapping paper

name: Process special orders for retail sales (SE:009) (CS)
definition:
involves handling customer requests for products not normally kept in stock.  
- Confirm customer needs  
- Place a special order with the supplier or manufacturer  
- Follow up to ensure the order is received and customer is satisfied

name: Sell gift certificates (SE:016) (CS)
definition:
The process of offering and providing gift certificates to customers as a way to promote sales and allow recipients to choose products or services later.  
- Present gift certificates to customers  
- Explain the value and terms of the gift certificates  
- Ensure proper recording and handling of the sales

name: Process retail telephone orders (SE:835) (CS)
definition:
The ability to take and record customer orders over the phone.  
- Answer customer calls  
- Collect order details (product, quantity, price)  
- Enter order information into the system

name: Process returns/exchanges (SE:162) (CS)
definition:
The ability to efficiently handle customer requests to return or exchange products.  
- Understanding store policies  
- Providing customer assistance during returns/exchanges  
- Completing the necessary paperwork or system updates

name: Process retail sales documentation (SE:117) (SP)
definition:
Understanding how to complete and manage paperwork related to retail sales.  
- Recording sales transactions  
- Handling receipts and invoices  
- Maintaining accurate sales records

name: Calculate miscellaneous charges for retail sales (SE:116) (CS)
definition:
Determine additional fees or costs added to a retail sale that are not included in the price of the product. Examples include:
- Delivery charges  
- Packaging fees  
- Service fees

name: Process sales transactions (e.g., cash, credit, check) (SE:329) (CS)
definition:
Process sales transactions involves completing sales by accepting payments through different methods.  
- Cash  
- Credit cards  
- Checks

name: Accept checks from customers (SE:152) (CS)
definition:
The ability to receive and process checks as a form of payment from customers.  
   - Verify the check's information  
   - Ensure funds are available if required  
   - Record the check transaction correctly

name: Operate register/terminal (SE:153) (CS)
definition:
The ability to use a cash register or sales terminal to process transactions.  
- Scan items or enter prices  
- Handle payments (cash, credit, debit)  
- Give receipts and change

name: Provide information about incoming merchandise to sales staff (SE:396) (SP)
definition:
Provide information about incoming merchandise to sales staff to help them understand new products and prepare for customer questions. This includes sharing details such as:
- Product features and benefits
- Pricing and promotional information
- Shipment arrival dates

name: Monitor on-floor selling activities (SE:389) (SP)
definition:
Observe and check the salesperson's actions during selling moments to ensure proper customer service and sales techniques.  
- Ensure salespeople follow company policies  
- Check for effective communication with customers  
- Confirm products are presented properly

name: Use digital media to enhance customer post-sales experience (CR:028) (SP)
definition:
Use digital media to improve the customer's experience after a purchase. This involves using online tools and platforms to communicate, support, and engage with customers post-sale. 

Examples include:
- Sending follow-up emails or surveys
- Providing how-to videos or tutorials
- Responding to customer questions on social media

name: Explain the nature and scope of distribution (OP:522) (CS)
definition:
Understanding distribution involves knowing how products are moved from producers to consumers. It includes the different types of channels and methods used to deliver products, as well as the coverage and reach of distribution strategies.

- Types of distribution channels (e.g., direct, indirect)
- Distribution methods (e.g., wholesale, retail)
- The extent or coverage of distribution efforts (local, regional, national)

name: Explain the relationship between customer service and distribution (OP:523) (CS)
definition:
**.**  
Customer service and distribution are connected because effective distribution ensures products are available to customers, which improves their experience. Good distribution supports customer service by delivering products accurately and on time.  
- Distribution makes products accessible to customers  
- Fast, reliable distribution enhances customer satisfaction  
- Customer feedback can influence distribution methods

name: Explain the nature of professional selling (PD:120) (SP)
definition:
Professional selling involves helping customers make informed buying decisions through ethical and knowledgeable interactions. It includes understanding customer needs and providing suitable solutions.  

- Building customer relationships  
- Communicating effectively and ethically  
- Providing product knowledge and service

name: Explain employment opportunities in professional selling (PD:055) (SP)
definition: Identify the different jobs available in professional selling, including roles such as sales representative, account manager, and sales manager.

name: Discuss the economic and social effects of professional selling (PD:131) (SP)
definition:
The DECA Performance Indicator "" means explaining how professional selling impacts the economy and society.  
This includes:

- How selling helps businesses grow and create jobs  
- How selling influences consumer choices and trust  
- The role of selling in building business relationships and community reputation

name: Identify professional certification requirements available for professional salespeople (PD:141) (SP)
definition:
Identify the professional certifications available for salespeople, which show they have special skills and knowledge in sales.  
- examples include:  
  - Certified Professional Sales Person (CPSP)  
  - Certified Sales Professional (CSP)  
  - Certified Professional in Sales Management (CPSM)

name: Assess the services of professional organizations in selling (PD:062) (SP)
definition:
.

Evaluate the different benefits and support services that professional organizations provide to sales professionals, such as:
- Networking opportunities
- Training and development programs
- Industry resources and information

name: Analyze market information (IM:301) (SP)
definition: Understand and evaluate data about a market to make informed business decisions. This includes examining trends, customer preferences, and competitor activity.

name: Describe the use of target marketing in professional selling (IM:334) (SP)
definition:
Target marketing in professional selling involves identifying and focusing on specific groups of potential customers to tailor sales efforts.  
- It helps salespeople understand customer needs better.  
- It allows for personalized messaging and offers.  
- It increases the chances of making a sale by concentrating on interested buyers.

name: Explain the impact of sales and buying cycles (SE:380) (SP)
definition:
This means understanding how the timing of sales and customer purchases affects a business. It involves recognizing how different times of the year or sales periods influence sales volume and business planning.  
- Sales and buying patterns change over time  
- Seasonal trends can increase or decrease sales  
- Businesses can plan marketing and inventory based on these cycles

name: Describe the impact that digital communication is having on selling (SE:490) (SP)
definition:
Digital communication is changing how sales are made. It allows businesses to reach customers quickly and interactively through online platforms.  

- It increases the speed and convenience of communication between sellers and buyers.  
- It enables personalized and targeted marketing efforts.  
- It provides new ways to build relationships and trust with customers.

name: Identify emerging trends for use in selling (SE:404) (SP)
definition:
Recognize new or developing patterns and changes in the market or customer behavior that can be used to improve sales strategies.  
- New technologies  
- Changing consumer preferences  
- Industry innovations

name: Differentiate between consumer and organizational buying behavior (SE:112) (SP)
definition:
**Differentiate between consumer and organizational buying behavior:**  
Understanding how individuals and organizations make purchase decisions.  
- Consumer buying behavior involves personal needs and wants.  
- Organizational buying behavior involves business needs and decision-making processes.

name: Explain the use of marketing-research information in professional selling (SE:383) (SP)
definition:
Use of marketing-research information in professional selling involves applying data gathered through research to better understand customer needs and improve sales strategies. This helps salespeople make informed decisions and tailor their approaches.  
- Analyze customer preferences and buying behaviors  
- Identify market trends and demand patterns  
- Develop effective sales pitches based on research data

name: Prospect for customers (SE:001) (SP)
definition:
The process of identifying and searching for potential customers who might be interested in a product or service.  

Examples include:
- Researching target markets
- Using social media to find potential buyers
- Collecting contact information from interested parties

name: Conduct preliminary customer/client qualification (SE:400) (SP)
definition:
The process of identifying and gathering basic information about potential customers or clients to determine their needs and likelihood of purchasing.  
- Collecting initial contact information  
- Asking questions to understand customer needs  
- Assessing customer interest and readiness to buy

name: competitors' offerings) (SE:369) (SP)
definition:
**Competitors' Offerings (SE:369) (SP)**

This refers to the products or services that competing businesses provide to the market.  
Examples include:
- Different brands of smartphones
- Various menu options at restaurants
- Types of clothing available in stores

name: Determine sales strategies (SE:377) (SP)
definition:
involves identifying and selecting methods to increase sales and meet sales goals.  
- Understand target customers  
- Choose appropriate sales techniques  
- Develop plans to attract and retain customers

name: Book appointments with prospective clients (SE:366) (SP)
definition:
The ability to schedule meetings with potential customers to discuss products or services.  
- Contact prospective clients  
- Find a convenient time for the meeting  
- Confirm the appointment details

name: Prepare sales presentation (SE:067) (SP)
definition:
Prepare a sales presentation (SE:067) (SP): Creating a plan to effectively explain and promote a product or service to a potential customer.  
- Identify the target audience  
- Highlight key features and benefits  
- Use visual aids or demonstrations

name: Prepare and/or assemble sales materials (SE:482) (SP)
definition:
This means creating or putting together items used to promote or sell products.  
- Examples include brochures, catalogs, samples, or displays.  
- The goal is to ensure all materials are ready for presenting to customers or for marketing efforts.

name: Build rapport and credibility with prospect (SE:483) (SP)
definition:
Build rapport and credibility with a prospect by establishing trust and a positive relationship. This involves:
- Listening actively to the prospect's needs
- Showing honesty and professionalism
- Demonstrating knowledge about the product or service

name: Respond appropriately to prospect's individual personality type (SE:810) (SP)
definition:
Respond appropriately to a prospect's individual personality type (SE:810) (SP).

This means recognizing and adjusting your communication and approach based on the prospect's personality or behavior style.  

- Understand different personality types
- Adapt your sales style to fit the prospect
- Build rapport by matching their communication preferences

name: Determine prospect's buying motives for use in selling (SE:883) (SP)
definition:
Determine a prospect's buying motives to better understand why they want to purchase a product.  
- Recognize the reasons or needs that influence the customer's decision  
- Use questions or listening skills to identify the customer's priorities and concerns

name: Facilitate prospect's buying decisions (SE:811) (SP)
definition:
Facilitate prospect's buying decisions means helping potential customers make a choice to purchase a product or service. This involves guiding them through the decision process and providing information or support.  
- Identify customer needs and concerns  
- Present solutions and benefits  
- Answer questions and address objections

name: (SE:484) (SP)
definition:
Develops personal and interpersonal skills necessary for success in the workplace.  
Includes:
- Communication skills
- Teamwork abilities
- Problem-solving skills

name: Assess prospect's needs in relation to product offering (SE:113) (SP)
definition:
This means identifying and understanding what a potential customer wants and needs to see how the company's products could meet those needs.  

Key elements include:
- Asking questions to learn about the customer's preferences
- Listening carefully to their responses
- Comparing their needs with the features of the product to see if it is a good match

name: Propose solution to prospect's needs/challenges (sales talk, sales proposal presentation) (SE:115)
definition:
Propose a solution to a prospect’s needs or challenges by presenting a sales talk or sales proposal. This involves suggesting how your product or service can solve the customer’s problem or meet their needs.

Elements include:
- Explaining the product or service clearly
- Highlighting how it benefits the customer
- Addressing the customer’s specific needs or challenges

name: Demonstrate product solution for prospect's needs (SE:893) (SP)
definition:
Show how a product or service meets the specific needs of a potential customer by explaining its features and benefits.  
- Identify the prospect's needs  
- Match product features to those needs  
- Explain how the product solves the prospect’s problem

name: Convert customer/client objections into selling points (SE:874) (SP)
definition:
This means turning a customer's concerns or reasons for hesitation into reasons to buy by highlighting benefits or solutions.  
- Understand the customer's objection  
- Respond with relevant information or benefits  
- Show how your product or service meets their needs

name: Close the sale (SE:895) (SP)
definition:
The ability to effectively finalize a sales transaction by encouraging the customer to make a purchase.  
- Address customer concerns  
- Summarize product benefits  
- Ask for the sale or next step

name: Negotiate sales terms/agreement (SE:392) (SP)
definition:
refers to the process of discussing and reaching an agreement on the conditions of a sale. 

This includes:
- Discussing prices and discounts
- Agreeing on delivery dates and methods
- Clarifying payment terms and responsibilities

name: Oversee fulfillment/completion of sale (SE:485) (SP)
definition:
Ensure that all steps of a sale are finished correctly, from processing the order to delivering the product or service.  
- Confirm that payment has been received  
- Coordinate delivery or service appointment  
- Follow up to ensure customer satisfaction

name: Sell good/service/idea to individuals (SE:046) (SP)
definition:
The ability to persuade and convince people to buy a product, service, or idea.  
   - Present benefits and features  
   - Address customer questions or concerns  
   - Use persuasive communication techniques

name: Sell good/service/idea to groups (SE:073) (SP)
definition:
The ability to persuade a group of people to buy a product, service, or idea.  
- Present information to the group  
- Address questions or concerns  
- Use persuasive techniques to influence their decision

name: Calculate miscellaneous charges (SE:475) (CS)
definition:
Determine and total additional fees or charges that do not fall into standard categories, such as:
- Service fees
- Delivery charges
- Special handling fees

name: Process special orders (SE:459) (SP)
definition:
The act of handling and completing customer requests for products that are not normally stocked or available in standard inventory.  

Examples include:  
- Confirming the order details with the customer  
- Checking availability with suppliers or vendors  
- Arranging for special delivery or delivery instructions

name: Process telephone orders (SE:461) (CS)
definition:
The ability to accurately take and record customer orders over the phone.  
- Listening carefully to customer requests  
- Writing down order details clearly  
- Confirming order accuracy with the customer

name: Process sales documentation (SE:474) (SP)
definition:
Refers to the steps involved in filling out and managing sales paperwork to record transaction details.  
- Completing sales receipts and invoices  
- Recording customer information and purchase details  
- Maintaining accurate sales records for reporting and future reference

name: Write product/service proposal (SE:486) (SP)
definition:
Write a product or service proposal that explains the idea, benefits, and details to convince others to approve or buy it.  
Includes:
- Clear description of the product or service
- Explanation of how it benefits the customer or business
- Details about costs, features, and how it will be delivered

name: Present proposal (SE:487) (SP)
definition:
The ability to prepare and deliver a clear and organized presentation of a plan or idea.  

- Identify the purpose and main points of the proposal  
- Organize supporting details logically  
- Communicate the proposal effectively to the audience

name: Plan follow-up strategies for use in selling (SE:057) (SP)
definition:
Develop a plan to stay in touch with customers after a sale to encourage future business.  
- Contact customers after the sale  
- Ask for feedback or reviews  
- Offer additional products or services

name: Prepare sales reports (SE:283) (SP)
definition:
Create written summaries that show sales data and performance.  
- Collect sales information  
- Organize data into the report  
- Analyze and summarize sales results

name: Provide post-sales service (SE:397) (SP)
definition:
Offering support and assistance to customers after a sale is completed to ensure their satisfaction.  
- Answer customer questions  
- Handle product returns or exchanges  
- Follow up to ensure proper use and satisfaction

name: Gather customer/client feedback to improve service (SE:384) (SP)
definition:
Collect opinions and suggestions from customers or clients to find ways to make the service better. This may include:
- Asking for opinions through surveys or conversations
- Listening to customer complaints or compliments
- Using feedback to make improvements in service quality

name: Conduct self-assessment of sales performance (SE:372) (SP)
definition:
Conduct a self-assessment of sales performance (SE:372) (SP) means evaluating your own sales efforts and results to identify areas for improvement.  
- Review your sales goals and achievements  
- Analyze your strengths and weaknesses in sales techniques  
- Set goals for improving future sales performance

name: Maintain ongoing relationship with client (SE:488) (SP)
definition:
Maintain an ongoing relationship with a client by staying in touch and providing support.  
- Communicate regularly with the client  
- Address any questions or concerns  
- Follow up to ensure satisfaction

name: Plan strategies for meeting sales quotas (SE:864) (SP)
definition:
Plan strategies for meeting sales quotas involves creating methods to achieve specific sales goals. This includes:
- Analyzing sales data
- Setting sales targets
- Developing action plans to reach sales objectives

name: Develop strategies to win back former customers (SE:379) (SP)
definition:
Develop strategies to win back former customers involves creating plans to reconnect with customers who previously purchased from the business and encourage them to return. This may include:

- Offering special promotions or discounts
- Improving customer service experiences
- Reaching out through personalized communication like emails or calls

name: Explain the nature of key account management (SE:381) (SP)
definition:
Key account management is the process of building strong, long-term relationships with important customers to meet their specific needs.  
- Focuses on large or high-value customers  
- Involves personalized service and communication  
- Aims to increase customer loyalty and business growth
